awd_titl_txt: Committee on Geological and Geotechnical Engineering and its Activities
awd_abstract_narration:
This award provides core funding for the Committee on Geological and Geotechnical Engineering (COGGE), a standing committee under the National Research Council's Board on Earth Sciences and Resources.   COGGE is the focal point within the Board on Earth Sciences and Resources for scientific, technical, and public-policy issues pertaining to the engineering applications of Earth Sciences. The committee's scope encompasses Earth processes and materials, including the mechanics of rock and soil, and focuses on safe and responsible human development, risk assessment, and mitigation of natural anthropogenic hazards. The committee organizes and oversees studies: 1) to identify, investigate, and report on questions relating to geological and geotechnical engineering to government, industry, academia, and the public; 2) to provide scientific and technical information to inform public policy on geological and geotechnical engineering issues; 3) to identify new technologies and potential applications; and,  4) to promote the acquisition and dissemination of knowledge.  In addition, the committee provides a forum for discussion among academic and professional groups, government agencies, and private industry to enhance national and international cooperation and exchange of information. 

The committee activity spans all areas of geological and geotechnical engineering, will identify new areas of needed research, and will provide increased understanding of the importance of geotechnology in addressing societal needs. The COGGE's mission is driven by the need to promote the responsibility of the geoengineer throughout the lifecycle of geoengineered facilities and structures; from site selection and facility design, to construction, operation, maintenance, and decommissioning. Issues include the geoengineering concerns associated with natural and built environments, radioactive and hazardous waste isolation and remediation, mitigation of natural hazards (e.g. earthquakes, landslides, rising sea levels), environmentally sound and safe recovery of natural resources, and interest in defense structures in rock. Projects undertaken, whether mandated by Congress, requested by federal agencies, or self-initiated, will be conducted by ad hoc committees under COGGE. Projects, governed by NRC guidelines, will result in peer-reviewed reports, and will provide geoengineering advice for decision makers.

por.por_cntn:
The Committee on Geological and Geotechnical Engineering (COGGE) is the focal point within the National Academies of Sciences, Engineering, and Medicine Board on Earth Sciences and Resources for scientific, technical, and public-policy issues pertaining to the engineering applications of Earth Sciences. The committee’s scope encompasses Earth processes and materials, including the mechanics of rock and soil, and focuses on safe and responsible human development, risk assessment, and mitigation of natural anthropogenic hazards. The committee organizes and oversees studies to identify, investigate, and report on questions relating to geological and geotechnical engineering to government, industry, academia, and the public; to inform public policy on geological and geotechnical engineering issues; to identify new  technologies and potential applications; and to promote the acquisition and dissemination of knowledge. In addition, the committee provides a forum for discussion among academic and professional groups, government agencies, and private industry to enhance national and international cooperation and exchange of information.

 

During the award period, COGGE volunteer membership of engineers and National Academies staff addressed a range of projects and initiatives that provided independent, unbiased, scientific advice and technical information on a broad set of geological and geotechnical engineering issues to decision and policy makers in Congress, federal and state government agencies, tribes, the research community, the private sector, non-governmental organizations, and the public.  COGGE’s activities also contributed toward understanding the interactions of fundamental geological and geotechnical processes and added to the knowledge base needed for society to steward and manage its critical resources to sustain the human and natural environments. While the work of the committee is not generally primary scholarship, COGGE represents the only voice of the technical community in Washington DC. Society benefits through better understanding of earth material behaviors, and of engineering best practices revealed through COGGE activities. COGGE helps to raise the profile of geological and geotechnical engineering to broad audiences and identify key issues for future work across diverse sectors, actors, and fields of study, thus having impact on research, practice, and policy.

COGGE convened and facilitated meetings, workshops, and webinars, and employed a variety of communication tools to provide scientific and technical information and forums for discussion with these stakeholders on topics such as: Real-time Monitoring and Assessment Technologies for Improved Underground Miner Safety and Health; Advancing the State of Practice in the Assessment of Earthquake-Induced Soil Liquefaction and Its Consequences; Corrosion of Buried Steel in Earth Applications; Large Deformation Modeling; Managing Mine Waste Risks; Assessment of Uncertainty in Determination of Design Parameters; and Incorporating Geo-professional Input into Improved Infrastructure Decision Making. Through its own consensus studies and those on which it collaborated, COGGE provided actionable recommendations to decision makers in government, academia, industry, and the non-profit sector on issues including those related to assessing underground coal mine dust exposures, managing flood and mudflow risks in rivers heavily affected by debris from the 1980 eruption of Mount St. Helens, strengthening the resilience of academic biomedical research to natural disasters, and related to the assessment of earthquake-induced soil liquefaction and its consequences.

During the performance period, COGGE has increased its outreach to its stakeholders by an order of magnitude, for example increasing registrants to its listserv from just a couple hundred at the beginning of the period to well over 3,000. With expanded use of remote meeting technologies, COGGE has increased participation in public meetings from 40-60 people to participation in the hundreds. And interest in COGGE has increased with the introduction of COGGE’s webinar series, which was as an intermittent activity at the beginning of the reporting period, but is now a quarterly event with attendance in the hundreds, including people from every state in the U.S. and many countries around the world. COGGE has supported the dissemination and broad reach of its consensus reports, measured by more than 12,000 downloads of free PDFs of the reports released during the performance period. This type of outreach aids in promoting new research avenues in geological and geotechnical engineering, and in advancing the intellectual basis for decision- and policy-making.
